I've been experimenting with the cross product domain and I think my 
findings might be of interest to some of you who may not have been 
following the discussion...

A 3D vector cross product can be calculated very simply with the formula 
Chad provided:

To calculate the cross product of vectors a and b

x = a1*b3 - a3*b2
y = a3*b1 - a1*b3
z = a1*b2 - a2*b1

It's a simple formula that only contains subtraction and multiplication, 
but it seems to be quite difficult to find a network to represent this 
forumla. Neural nets of the knid we use are good at adding(and therfore 
subtracting) because each neuron adds it's inputs, but what about 
multiplication?

I tried a simple multiplication experiment and discovered that although 
networks can be found, that they are not trivial. Typically they will 
have at least 4 hidden nodes to get the basic functionality and more 
nodes are required for extra accuracy. Now consider that for a network 
to calculate a cross product it must independently discover six 
multiplication sub-networks, connected up so that their result is 
combined appropriately. Hopefully this gives some idea of why the cross 
product domain is a non-trivial one.

A quick google came up with this paper which investigates neurons that 
multiply their inputs instead of adding them:

http://gs37.sp.cs.cmu.edu/papers/files/mult-NN-complexity2.pdf

I havent read it yet but I tried out the concept and sure enough I can 
find a network that performs multiplication just by connecting the two 
input (operand) neurons directly to the output, all the NEAT search 
needs to do is find the appropriate two weights. Some accuracy is lost 
because the answer passes through the sigmoid function, but it's about 
as accurate as the networks found using adding neurons.

I then tried the cross product domain again, this time with the 
multiplying neurons and a manually created seed genome with all the 
connections required to perform cross product. The result was failure, 
presumably because although the multiplication part is now being 
performed by the network, the additive (or subtraction) part of the 
formula is now more difficult to achieve with multiplying neurons. doh! 
So perhaps it would be an idea to mix adding and multiplying neurons? So 
now I'm wondering what other domains might benefit from the inclusion of 
multiplying neurons into our various NEAT implementations? For starters 
John's image enlargment might benefit, as might Derek and Philips roving 
eye (with a zoom factor).

Colin
